awd_titl_txt: Radio Stars: from kHz to THz
awd_abstract_narration:
The conference will bring together researchers and students, observers and theorists for the presentation and discussion of new advances in stellar astrophysics enabled by the latest generation of radio facilities operating from meter to submillimeter wavelengths.  

The general focus of the workshop will be radio emission from hot and cool stars during the pre-main sequence through post-main sequence evolutionary phases.  An underlying theme will be exploring how the new technologies that are opening the entire radio spectrum to the study of the Sun and stars are leading to new discoveries.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This award supported an international workshop titled "Radio Stars: from kHz to THz", hosted by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Haystack Observatory from November 1-3, 2017. This meeting was attended by more than 50 scientists from across the US and around the world.

Intellectual Merit

During the past few years, the availability of the latest generation of radio telescopes has been leading to a rapid pace of discoveries in nearly every branch of stellar astrophysics. The "Radio Stars" meeting was conceived to provide a forum for the presentation and discussion of these new findings and enhance our understanding of how radio wavelength observations can provide unique insights into the birth, evolution, and deaths of stars.

Radio emission has now been detected from stars spanning virtually every type and evolutionary stage. Depending on the type of star, this radio emission can originate from a wide variety of physical processes, and observations of stars at meter through submillimeter wavelengths probe a broad range of astrophysical phenomena that cannot be studied by any other means. Recent game-changing discoveries in stellar astrophysics enabled by radio wavelength observations that were discussed at the meeting include:

  • The detection of pulsed emission from ultracool dwarf stars (including brown dwarfs)
  • Evidence of magnetic field reversals on stars other than the Sun
  • The discovery of gamma rays from novae
  • Evidence for ongoing star formation in the environment close to the black hole at the center of the Milky Way Galaxy
  • The detection of new molecules in the ejecta of dying stars.

These discoveries have been enabled in full or in part by a range of NSF-supported facilities, including The Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array (VLA), the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA), and the Very Long Baseline Array (VLBA).

Broader Impacts

The organizers of the Radio Stars meeting actively sought participation from researchers spanning a diverse range in age, gender, career state, national origin, and professional position. The meeting was well-attended by students and early career researchers and thus provided valuable professional training opportunities.

Summary of Outcomes

The "Radio Stars" meeting provided a forum for the exchange of new ideas and enabled the forging of new collaborations between researchers.

Presentations and audio content from the meeting have been publicly posted on the meeting web site: https://www.haystack.mit.edu/workshop/Radio-Stars2017/. A review article has been published in Publications of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific to provide a detailed summary of the topics and ideas discussed at the meeting (Matthews 2019, PASP, 131, 016001).
